issues.text: Whether the respondent was under a legal obligation to pay one-sixth of the annual fee within seven days of the auction under cl. 21 of r. 5.34 and liable for the deficiency in price and all expenses of resale under cl. 22 of r. 5.34?

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants it was contended by Dr. Seyid Muhammad that the respondent was under a legal obligation to pay one-sixth of the annual fee within seven days of the auction under cl. 21 of r. 5.34 and it. was due to his default that a resale of the excise shep was ordered.

issues.text: Whether the phrase 'person to whom a shop has been sold' in cl. 21 of r. 5.34 means a person whose bid has been provisionally accepted by the auction officer?

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted on behalf of the appellant that the phrase person to whom a shop has been sold in cl. 21 of r. 5.34 means a person whose bid has been provisionally accepted.

issues.text: Whether the contract of sale was complete upon closure of the auction or only after confirmation of the bid by the Chief Commissioner?

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear that the contract of sale was number complete till the bid was confirmed by the Chief Commissioner and till such confirmation the person whose bid has been provisionally accepted is entitled to withdraw his bid.

issues.text: Whether the acceptance of the highest bid at auction was conditional, allowing the bidder to withdraw until absolute acceptance by the Chief Commissioner?

anchor.surface_text: An acceptance of an offer may be either absolute or conditional. If the acceptance is conditional the offer can be withdrawn at any moment until absolute acceptance has taken place. This view is borne out by the decision of the Court of Appeal in Hussey v. HornePayne

arguments.claim: The respondent was under a legal obligation to pay one-sixth of the annual fee within seven days of the auction under cl. 21 of r. 5.34 and due to his default a resale was ordered, making him liable for the deficiency in price and all expenses of such resale under cl. 22 of r. 5.34.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants it was contended by Dr. Seyid Muhammad that the respondent was under a legal obligation to pay one-sixth of the annual fee within seven days of the auction under cl. 21 of r. 5.34 and it. was due to his default that a resale of the excise shep was ordered. Under cl. 22 of r. 5.34 the respondent was liable for the deficiency in price and all expenses of such resale which was caused by his default.

arguments.court_reasoning: First part of cl. 21 deals with completed sale; second part applies to auctions by officer lower than Collector; Chief Commissioner disapproved bid.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed that no completed contract until confirmation; bid subject to cl. 33, 16, 18.

arguments.court_reasoning: Cl. 33 valid; sale not complete until confirmation as per rules and conditions.

arguments.claim: The contract of sale was not complete till the bid was confirmed by the Chief Commissioner and till such confirmation the person whose bid has been provisionally accepted is entitled to withdraw his bid without liability for damages or shortfall on resale.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this argument. The first portion of cl. 21 requires the person to whom the shop has been sold to deposit one-sixth of the total annual fee within seven days. But the sale is deemed to have been made in favour of the highest bidder only on the completion of the formalities before the conclusion of the sale. Clause 16 of r. 5.34 states that all sales are open to revision by the Chief Commissioner.

arguments.claim: An acceptance of an offer may be either absolute or conditional; if conditional, the offer can be withdrawn until absolute acceptance, as in Hussey v. Horne-Payne.

anchor.surface_text: An acceptance of an offer may be either absolute or conditional. If the acceptance is conditional the offer can be withdrawn at any moment until absolute acceptance has taken place. This view is borne out by the decision of the Court of Appeal in Hussey v. HornePayne . In that case V offered land to P and P accepted subject to the title being approved by my solicitors.

arguments.claim: The first part of cl. 21 deals with a completed sale and the second part deals with a situation where the auction is conducted by an officer lower in rank than the Collector; recoverable only from defaulting bidder in that case.
It is not disputed that the Chief Commissioner disapproved the bid; absent confirmation under cl. 33, no completed transaction and no liability for deficiency.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that the Chief Commissioner has disapproved the bid offered by the respondent. If the Chief Commissioner had granted sanction under cl. 33 of Ex. D-28 the auction sale in favour of the respondent would have been a completed transaction and he would have been liable for any shortfall on the resale.

holdings.text: The respondent was not under a legal obligation to pay one-sixth of the annual fee within seven days of the auction under cl. 21 of r. 5.34 and is not liable for the deficiency in price and all expenses of resale under cl. 22 of r. 5.34.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this argument. The first portion of cl. 21 requires the person to whom the shop has been sold to deposit one-sixth of the total annual fee within seven days. But the sale is deemed to have been made in favour of the highest bidder only on the completion of the formalities before the conclusion of the sale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sale not complete until formalities including Chief Commissioner's confirmation under clauses 16, 18 of r. 5.34 and cl. 33; first part of cl. 21 applies to completed sales only.

holdings.text: The contract of sale was not complete till the bid was confirmed by the Chief Commissioner and till such confirmation the person whose bid has been provisionally accepted is entitled to withdraw his bid.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear that the contract of sale was number complete till the bid was confirmed by the Chief Commissioner and till such confirmation the person whose bid has been provisionally accepted is entitled to withdraw his bid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl. 33 makes bids subject to confirmation; clauses 16 and 18 indicate revision process; no binding contract pre-confirmation.

holdings.text: When the bid is so withdrawn before the confirmation of the Chief Commissioner the bidder will not be liable for damages on account of any breach of contract or for the shortfall on the resale.

anchor.surface_text: When the bid is so withdrawn before the confirmation of the Chief Commissioner the bidder will not be liable for damages on account of any breach of contract or for the shortfall on the resale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No completed contract exists pre-confirmation, so no breach liability.

holdings.text: The acceptance of the bid was conditional, allowing withdrawal until absolute acceptance by the Chief Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: An acceptance of an offer may be either absolute or conditional. If the acceptance is conditional the offer can be withdrawn at any moment until absolute acceptance has taken place. This view is borne out by the decision of the Court of Appeal in Hussey v. HornePayne

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conditional acceptance under common law principle, analogous to Hussey v. Horne-Payne; cl. 33 imposes condition of confirmation.

holdings.text: The phrase 'person to whom a shop has been sold' in cl. 21 of r. 5.34 does not mean a person whose bid has been provisionally accepted by the auction officer; it refers to a completed sale.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading distinguishes first part (completed sale) from second part (provisional by lower officer); Chief Commissioner disapproved bid.

holdings.text: There is no liability imposed on the respondent for payment of the deficiency in the price as the essential pre-requisites of a completed sale are missing.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Bid disapproved by Chief Commissioner; no confirmation under cl. 33; contrasts with scenario if confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: Hussey v. HornePayne 1 . In that case V offered land to P and P accepted subject to the title being approved by my solicitors. V later refused to go on with the companytract and the Court of Appeal held that the acceptance was companyditional and there was numberbinding companytract and that V companyld withdraw at any time Until Ps solicitors had approved the title. Jessel, M.R. observed at p. 626 of the report as follows The offer made to the Plaintiff of the estate at that price was a simple offer companytaining numberreference whatever to title.

precedents.cited_proposition: Acceptance of an offer subject to a condition such as approval of title by solicitors is conditional and does not create a binding contract until the condition is fulfilled, allowing withdrawal before absolute acceptance.
precedents.cited_holding: the acceptance was conditional and there was no binding contract and that V could withdraw at any time until P's solicitors had approved the title; 'The expression subject to the title being approved by our solicitors appears to me to be plainly an additional term.'

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this argument. The first portion of cl. 21 requires the person to whom the shop has been sold to deposit one-sixth of the total annual fee within seven days. But the sale is deemed to have been made in favour of the highest bidder only on the completion of the formalities before the conclusion of the sale.
For these reasons we hold that the judgment of the Punjab High Court dated August 19, 1963 in L.P.A. No.
